review.title: We Tweet Like We Talk and Other Interesting Observations: An Analysis of English Communication Modalities
review.abstract: Modalities of communication for human beings are gradually increasing in number with the advent of new forms of technology. Many human beings can readily transition between these different forms of communication with little or no effort, which brings about the question: How similar are these different communication modalities? To understand technology$\text{'}$s influence on English communication, four different corpora were analyzed and compared: Writing from Books using the 1-grams database from the Google Books project, Twitter, IRC Chat, and transcribed Talking. Multi-word confusion matrices revealed that Talking has the most similarity when compared to the other modes of communication, while 1-grams were the least similar form of communication analyzed. Based on the analysis of word usage, word usage frequency distributions, and word class usage, among other things, Talking is also the most similar to Twitter and IRC Chat. This suggests that communicating using Twitter and IRC Chat evolved from Talking rather than Writing. When we communicate online, even though we are writing, we do not Tweet or Chat how we write books; we Tweet and Chat how we Speak. Nonfiction and Fiction writing were clearly differentiable from our analysis with Twitter and Chat being much more similar to Fiction than Nonfiction writing. These hypotheses were then tested using author and journalists Cory Doctorow. Mr. Doctorow$\text{'}$s Writing, Twitter usage, and Talking were all found to have very similar vocabulary usage patterns as the amalgamized populations, as long as the writing was Fiction. However, Mr. Doctorow$\text{'}$s Nonfiction writing is different from 1-grams and other collected Nonfiction writings. This data could perhaps be used to create more entertaining works of Nonfiction.

metadata.title: We Tweet Like We Talk and Other Interesting Observations: An Analysis of Modalities of English Communication

sections.text: To understand the impact of technology on English communication, four different corpora were analyzed and compared: letters from books using the 1 gram database of the Google Books project, Twitter, IRC chat, and transcribed speaking. Multi-word confusion matrices showed that speaking is the most similar to other forms of communication, while 1 gram was the least similar form of communication analyzed. Based on the analysis of word usage, the frequency of word use, and the use of words in the word class, among other things, it was found that speaking is most similar to Twitter and IRC chat. This suggests that communication via Twitter and IRC chat originated from speaking, not from writing.

sections.heading: INTRODUCTION
sections.text: The evolution of new spoken language dialects has often been studied and modeled in terms of the contribution of idiolects (1) and the effects of spatial pressure (2). Since technology enables easy communication between spatially distant individuals, it is possible that modern dialects can form between members of social networks without similar geographical locations. This raises a somewhat semantic question: What constitutes a dialect? It is clear that graphic communication can be very different from phonomic communication, as these are presented as a combination of phonemic and graphic dialects in English (3). Overall, however, this question is complicated and overlooks a simpler question: How similar or different are communication corporas from each other? In the past 25-30 years, modes of online communication, such as chat, appear as a combination of phonemic and graphic dialects, but it is unclear how different these modes of communication are from each other.

sections.heading: METHODS
sections.text: The Google N-gram project has attempted to create a comprehensive database of word usage in written books. A direct statistical interpretation of the corpus should be approached with caution; the corpus digitizes all symbolic representations in a book, including numbers, letters and symbols. For example, "70%" is considered gram. Google also acknowledges on its website that the degree of optical character recognition (OCR) is not perfect. These errors can make it difficult to define the likelihood of occurrence of Ngrams, as the same word could be inappropriately identified as two different words. I used the corpus in 2009, as this project was started before the Corpus in 2012. Each non-letter-based gram was parsed, so that each gram was removed with numbers, punctuation or non-Arabic characters.

sections.heading: Twitter
sections.text: For the Twitter corpus, the live English Twitter stream was searched for a space. "This eliminated any bias in the data stream and distorted it when tweeting with spaces. Tweets that only contained links to websites were removed and only unique tweets were included in the analysis. The resulting Twitter corpus comprises over 1.25 million unique tweets and over 12 million counts and approximately 3 million unique words.

sections.heading: IRC Chat logs
sections.text: The IRC chat logs relate to two different chat channels: In IRC chat, when people specifically respond to another person, the sentence begins with "< name >:" I have removed them to avoid erroneous results that make names appear to be heavily used.

sections.heading: Talking or Spoken Word (Santa Barbara Corpus of Spoken American English)
sections.text: This corpus of SBCSAE contains many different kinds of human conversation. It is the smallest corpus with only about 250,000 counts and about 11,000 unique words. I am not implying that my corpora is perfect by any means. There are flaws in them at first and flaws through difficult parsing. What I want to say is that I have tried to make the corpus as flawless as necessary.

sections.heading: Cory Doctorow Corpora
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: Talking
sections.text: This data comes from transcribed lectures and questions and answers by Mr. Doctorow, which he received via the video service Youtube. Cory Doctorow is a multi-media author, which made him an ideal candidate. This corpus comprises 22,962 counts and 3,794 unique words.

sections.heading: Twitter
sections.text: That is about 500 tweets from Mr Doctorow, because that is all you can get from Twitter after analysing the tweets that only contained links, and this body contains 2,990 total numbers and 1,383 unique words.

sections.heading: Fiction
sections.text: This corpus contains the freely available works Down and Out in the Magic Kingdom and Little Brother. This compromises 237,958 total counts and 12,118 unique words.

sections.heading: Nonfiction
sections.text: Contains works from Mr. Doctorow's nonfiction books, blogs and opinion articles. It contains 22,187 points and 4,757 unique words.

sections.heading: RESULTS & DISCUSSION
sections.text: To estimate the frequency distribution of words, histograms were generated by random sampling of corpora. > 90% of the words of each corpora fall into the smallest frequency counter, unless I make the trash ridiculously small (i.e. a thousand or a million times smaller than the word with the most counts) (data are not shown), which found that most of the data in the corpora are rarely used words. Thus, for example, of the 3,769,991 unique words extracted from Google 1-gram, the most are used at 20,510,449,496 times (~ 8% of the corpus), while the 10,000 most commonly used word words are used 1,813,662 times (~ 7x10 -6% of the corpus) and the 100,000 word-holders are used only 3330,001 times (~ 1x10 -7% of the corpus). Of the 3.7 million words most frequently used, approximately one billion times less than the most frequently used word.

sections.text: This year it is more than ever before.

sections.heading: Matching words
sections.text: If we look at the number of matching words in the top 200 populations, we see that Twitter and Talk match best with 142 out of 200 matching words, or 71% (Table 3). While Twitter and 1-gram match worst with only 115 or 57.5% of the same words, Twitter and chat seem to be very similar in the composition of the words, with 70% matching.

sections.heading: Copora Similarity and Confusion
sections.text: The confusion matrices used in each corpus are similar, but also if their frequency of usage is similar. The confusion matrices were created on the premise that if a word is randomly selected from a random corpus and I try to determine which corpus the word came from based on usage frequency alone not my a priori knowledge of origin, can I do it? An example would be if I randomly select a word from the Twitter corpus, but based on our statistics that it came from the 1 gram corpus, then it is said that the word is "confused." It means that I cannot correctly guess based on my best guess method alone with no a priori knowledge. I did not want to do this with just one word, but with several words to construct a sentence like analysis. So, instead of looking for the probability of just one word, I looked for a combined probability of several words.

sections.heading: Case Study
sections.text: I met the author Cory Doctorow and decided to use his corpora because he has open and free books available, which I have converted into 1 gram, a Twitter account and videos of him speaking and interacting on Youtube. All of Mr. Doctorow's works correspond to very similar distributions (fig. 6), which was quite unexpected compared to the amalgamated populations composed of many different authors above. Mr. Doctorow's 1 gram resemble Twitter and Talk more than they resemble Google's 1 gram distributions. Again, the distribution of Google 1 gram is completely different compared to all the other distributions. Why is that? As you can see from the Doctorow data, it is not an intrinsic property of books. The books used by Mr. Doctorow are all fiction and so different distributions.

INTRODUCTION The evolution of new dialects of spoken languages has often been studied and modeled with respect to the contribution of idiolects (1) and the impact of spatial pressures (2). With technology allowing ease of communication between spatially distant individuals, there is the possibility that modern dialects may form between members of social networks without similar geographical locations. This raises a somewhat semantic question: What constitutes a dialect? It is clear that graphemic communication can be very different from phonemic communication, as these have been suggested to be different dialects in English (3). However, overall this question is complicated and overlooks a simpler question: How similar or different are communication corpora from each other? In the past 25-30 years modes of online communication, such as Chat, appear as a combination of phonemic and graphemic dialects, but it is unclear how much these modes differ. Modern modalities of communication were developed on the basis of previous forms of communication, but it is unclear if the language usage is more similar to written or spoken “dialects”. In this study, I have analyzed the vocabulary from four different bodies of work: books from the Google Books project (4), chat logs from IRC, transcribed verbal communication (i.e., Talking), and over one million unique messages sent on Twitter. What I find is unexpected. Though Chat and Twitter could be considered forms of written communication, the word usage patterns are more similar to Talking. Comparisons between Fiction and Nonfiction writing show that Fiction more closely resembles Chat and Twitter. Using a case study of Author, Speaker and Twitter user Cory Doctorow I find that the way someone speaks can be as similar to Nonfiction writing as it is to Fiction writing but we incorrigibly Tweet like we speak.
